author: HCAndersen
text: THERE was an old mansion surrounded by a marshy ditch with a drawbridge which was but seldom let down:- not all guests are good people.

author: HCAndersen
text: Under the roof were loopholes to shoot through, and to pour down boiling water or even molten lead on the enemy, should he approach.

author: HCAndersen
text: Inside the house the rooms were very high and had ceilings of beams, and that was very useful considering the great deal of smoke which rose up from the chimney fire where the large, damp logs of wood smouldered.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the walls hung pictures of knights in armour and proud ladies in gorgeous dresses; the most stately of all walked about alive.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was called Meta Mogen; she was the mistress of the house, to her belonged the castle.

author: HCAndersen
text: Towards the evening robbers came; they killed three of her people and also the yard-dog, and attached Mrs. Meta to the kennel by the chain, while they themselves made good cheer in the hall and drank the wine and the good ale out of her cellar.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mrs. Meta was now on the chain, she could not even bark.

author: HCAndersen
text: But lo! the servant of one of the robbers secretly approached her; they must not see it, otherwise they would have killed him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Mrs. Meta Mogen," said the fellow, "do you still remember how my father, when your husband was still alive, had to ride on the wooden horse?

author: HCAndersen
text: You prayed for him, but it was no good, he was to ride until his limbs were paralysed; but you stole down to him, as I steal now to you, you yourself put little stones under each of his feet that he might have support, nobody saw it, or they pretended not to see it, for you were then the young gracious mistress.

author: HCAndersen
text: My father has told me this, and I have not forgotten it!

author: HCAndersen
text: Now I will free you, Mrs. Meta Mogen!"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they pulled the horses out of the stable and rode off in rain and wind to obtain the assistance of friends.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Thus the small service done to the old man was richly rewarded!" said Meta Mogen.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Delaying is not forgetting," said the fellow.

author: HCAndersen
text: The robbers were hanged.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was an old mansion, it is still there; it did not belong to Mrs. Meta Mogen, it belonged to another old noble family.

author: HCAndersen
text: We are now in the present time.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sun is shining on the gilt knob of the tower, little wooded islands lie like bouquets on the water, and wild swans are swimming round them.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the garden grow roses; the mistress of the house is herself the finest rose petal, she beams with joy, the joy of good deeds: however, not done in the wide world, but in her heart, and what is preserved there is not forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
text: Delaying is not forgetting!

author: HCAndersen
text: Now she goes from the mansion to a little peasant hut in the field.

author: HCAndersen
text: Therein lives a poor paralysed girl; the window of her little room looks northward, the sun does not enter here.

author: HCAndersen
text: The girl can only see a small piece of field which is surrounded by a high fence.

author: HCAndersen
text: But to-day the sun shines here- the warm, beautiful sun of God is within the little room; it comes from the south through the new window, where formerly the wall was.

author: HCAndersen
text: The paralysed girl sits in the warm sunshine and can see the wood and the lake; the world had become so large, so beautiful, and only through a single word from the kind mistress of the mansion.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The word was so easy, the deed so small," she said, "the joy it afforded me was infinitely great and sweet!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And therefore she does many a good deed, thinks of all in the humble cottages and in the rich mansions, where there are also afflicted ones.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is concealed and hidden, but God does not forget it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Delayed is not forgotten!

author: HCAndersen
text: An old house stood there; it was in the large town with its busy traffic.

author: HCAndersen
text: There are rooms and halls in it, but we do not enter them, we remain in the kitchen, where it is warm and light, clean and tidy; the copper utensils are shining, the table as if polished with beeswax; the sink looks like a freshly scoured meatboard.

author: HCAndersen
text: All this a single servant has done, and yet she has time to spare as if she wished to go to church; she wears a bow on her cap, a black bow, that signifies mourning.

author: HCAndersen
text: But she has no one to mourn, neither father nor mother, neither relations nor sweetheart.

author: HCAndersen
text: She is a poor girl.

author: HCAndersen
text: One day she was engaged to a poor fellow; they loved each other dearly.

author: HCAndersen
text: One day he came to her and said: "We both have nothing!

author: HCAndersen
text: The rich widow over the way in the basement has made advances to me; she will make me rich, but you are in my heart; what do you advise me to do?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I advise you to do what you think will turn out to your happiness," said the girl.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Be kind and good to her, but remember this; from the hour we part we shall never see each other again."

author: HCAndersen
text: Years passed; then one day she met the old friend and sweetheart in the street; he looked ill and miserable, and she could not help asking him, "How are you?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Rich and prospering in every respect," he said; "the woman is brave and good, but you are in my heart.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have fought the battle, it will soon be ended; we shall not see each other again now until we meet before God!"

author: HCAndersen
text: A week has passed; this morning his death was in the newspaper, that is the reason of the girl's mourning!

author: HCAndersen
text: Her old sweetheart is dead and has left a wife and three step-children, as the paper says; it sounds as if there is a crack, but the metal is pure.

author: HCAndersen
text: The black bow signifies mourning, the girl's face points to the same in a still higher degree; it is preserved in the heart and will never be forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
text: Delaying is not forgetting!

author: HCAndersen
text: These are three stories you see, three leaves on the same stalk.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do you wish for some more trefoil leaves?

author: HCAndersen
text: In the little heartbook are many more of them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Delaying is not forgetting!
